Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with hx of breast cancer on tamoxifen, 
dCHF, CKD, HTN, and poorly controlled IDDM who p/w emesisx1, 
hyperglycemia and found to be hyponatremic

# Hyperglycemia (oorly controlled insulin-dependent DM type II). 
Patient's sugars improved while inpatient. A1c checked was 9.5 
(up from 8.8). Etiology of hyperglycemia unclear (? brief viral 
infection). She was slightly hypoglycemic on one night given 
high ISS, but was stable once her home ISS was re-initiated.
Continued home NPH insulin (20 QAM, 10 QPM) and ISS of Humalog 1 
unit for ___ 100-150, 1 units for 150-200, 2 units for 201-250, 4 
units for 250-300, 6 units for 300-350, 8 units for 350-400, 10 
units for >400

# N/V without abdominal pain: patient reported 1 episode of 
this. This resolved prior to hospitalization and etiology is 
unclear. She was stable while inpatient.

# Hyponatremia: Probably was due to hypovolemic hyponatremia in 
the setting of emesis and poor PO intake and likely glucosuria. 
Discharge sodium was 140.

# Chronic confusion: her niece/caretaker reports this is 
ongoing, waxing/ waning, but gradually progressive and manifests 
primarily as poor recall of recent events and instructions. Has 
not had changes in her attention or orientation during recent 
illness as far as family is aware or on exam and was stable 
through hospitalization

# Microcytic anemia: near baseline. Of note patient gets iron 
with medication package at home.

# ___ with possible exacerbation: Cxray on admission without 
pulmonary edema or vascular congestion. She was placed back on 
her home diuretics once electrolytes improved.

# CKD: Cr & BUN at approximately her baseline

# HTN: home BP regimen included clonidine 0.3 mg daily which we 
stopped. She was normotensive with just her lisinopril 10mg 
daily

# AFib on apixiban: continued on apixiban

# Hx of breast cancer: continued home tamoxifen

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES
====================
- Home clonidine was stopped given normotensive on lisinopril 
10mg. Reassess in outpatient and consider restarting or placing 
on a calcium channel blocker.
- Needs close monitoring of ___ to ensure not hypoglycemic. 
Currently appears to be doing well on home regimen while 
inpatient
